verses.text: He who shows mercy lends to his neighbor, and he who supports him with a helping hand keeps the commandments.
verses.comment: This verse connects the act of lending and mercy directly to obedience to God’s law, showing practical love. The emphasis on works highlights a holistic approach to faith and charity.

verses.text: Lend to your neighbor when he is in need, and repay your neighbor on time.
verses.comment: Both generosity and responsibility are stressed. Lending is encouraged as a work of mercy, yet prompt repayment respects justice.

verses.text: Keep your word and be trustworthy, and you will always find what you need.
verses.comment: Integrity is presented as essential for prosperous relationships and divine blessing.

verses.text: Many regard a loan as something to be found, and they put those who help them to trouble.
verses.comment: This verse warns about the danger of ingratitude and the obligation to honor financial debts, reflecting biblical warnings against carelessness.

verses.text: Until he receives, he kisses your hand and talks humbly about your wealth. But when it's time to pay, he delays and blames circumstances.
verses.comment: There is a subtle warning about false humility and unreliability, a vice that disrupts trust within the community.

verses.text: If he can repay, he might do so, but if not, he takes away your money and makes you his enemy for no reason.
verses.comment: This passage reflects on the brokenness of sin when obligations are avoided, underscoring the societal need for justice and charity.

verses.text: He curses you instead of offering thanks, and repays your good with evil. People will avoid him, so he cannot find a friend.
verses.comment: Ungratefulness severs bonds and isolates the individual—an implicit call for reconciliation and restoration within the community.

verses.text: Lend to the poor, and you will not lose; indeed, you will be repaid with greater blessings.
verses.comment: The promise of divine recompense for charity, anticipating the teaching of Jesus on giving generously.

verses.text: Defend the rights of the poor and do not leave them in desperate need.
verses.comment: Active defense of the poor is commended—a theme closely related to biblical justice and mercy.

verses.text: Give your money to keep your brother or friend from poverty, and do not hide it under a stone to rust away.
verses.comment: Implied rebuke against hoarding wealth, encouraging it be put to use in service of others, echoing parables of stewardship.

verses.text: Use your wealth for your brother and your friend, that it may be returned to you someday when you need it.
verses.comment: Generosity is presented as an investment, not only earthly but with eternal reward—foreshadows Christ's teachings on repayment in the life to come.

verses.text: Spend your treasure according to the commandments of the Most High, and it will yield you more profit than gold.
verses.comment: Faithfully following divine law in the use of resources is blessed with spiritual reward, valuing God’s will over material gain.

verses.text: Store up your almsgiving in the heart of the poor, and it will intercede for you against all evil.
verses.comment: Charitable works are shown to possess spiritual power—almsgiving being a means of intercession and protection.

verses.text: Better to give alms than to hoard treasure, for almsgiving delivers from death and purges away every sin.
verses.comment: Direct statement about the spiritual efficacy of charitable works for salvation and forgiveness, resonating with New Testament teaching on works and faith.

verses.text: Whoever gives alms will be satisfied with life, and whoever fails to do so will face judgment.
verses.comment: Highlights the eschatological dimension—charity as a factor in the final judgment, in line with Christ’s parable of the sheep and goats.

verses.text: Lend to your neighbor in time of need, and repay your debt in good faith.
verses.comment: Reiterates the virtue of meeting others’ needs out of one’s abundance—a foundational principle of Christian community.

verses.text: Keep your promises and act honestly, and on every occasion you will be respected.
verses.comment: Honesty forms the basis for good reputation, implicitly instructing believers to be trustworthy stewards.

verses.text: Many treat a loan as found money and cause trouble for those who helped them.
verses.comment: Warns against abusing a brother’s generosity—promotes the honest handling of what is entrusted to us.

verses.text: Until he gets the loan, he will kiss the lender’s hand, speak humbly and offer many promises. But when repayment is due, he delays and blames circumstances.
verses.comment: Reminds us to be wary of flattery and ensure genuine relationships grounded in transparency.

verses.text: He will pay if he can, but if not, he has stolen your money and made you his enemy needlessly.
verses.comment: This echoes the warning against defaulting on commitments—a matter of social justice and spiritual responsibility.

verses.text: Repaying evil for good, he curses you instead of thanking you, and people will avoid him and never lend to him again.
verses.comment: Consistent social consequences of distrust highlight the value of faithfulness and accountability in God’s family.

verses.text: A good person will continue to lend, but for his own safety will not go beyond what is wise.
verses.comment: A prudent balance between generosity and discernment is recommended—practical wisdom in Christian stewardship.

verses.text: Do not be ashamed to help someone; even when misfortune falls, your kindness will not be forgotten.
verses.comment: Assures that acts of kindness have lasting value—earthly and spiritual rewards come from faithful generosity.

verses.text: Store up your good works for times of trouble, and they will save you from every distress.
verses.comment: The concept of ‘treasure in heaven’ shines through, foreshadowing Jesus’ teaching on the prudence of spiritual investments.

verses.text: Better to live with little in peace than to depend on others and wander as a beggar.
verses.comment: Spiritual contentment prioritizes peace over abundance. A subtle reference to humility and reliance on God’s provision.

verses.text: Live quietly and enjoy the necessities; do not let another’s table make your soul anxious.
verses.comment: Peace and interior freedom in one’s own life is extolled—echoes ascetic wisdom found throughout Scripture.

verses.text: If you must depend on another for food, you will have bitter anxiety and lose your self-respect.
verses.comment: Independence is valued, yet the call throughout is not for selfishness but balanced self-reliance and sacrificial love.

verses.text: You will hear harsh words and be shamed, and your hope will be uncertain.
verses.comment: Concludes with a warning about the insecurity of debt—true hope and dignity come from trust in God and practical wisdom.
